QC.Acc01.description: Is the source code managed with a Version Control System?
QC.Acc01.hint: The source code shall be managed with Git and remain publicly available for this criterion to be successful. Please check Pro Git docs about how to get started using Git tool. Guidelines provided by the most popular social coding platforms (GitHub, GitLab) are also a good starting point

evidence.message: Source code uses Git for version control

standard.title: A set of Common Software Quality Assurance Baseline Criteria for Research Projects

QC.Doc06.1.description: Is the software scope outlined in the code repository?
QC.Doc06.1.hint: A README file presents your software to the audience interested in your software project. Several online sites simplify the task of creating the README file, such as Make a README or readme.so sites. Be sure to add it to the code repository's root path

evidence.message: A README file is present in the code repository

standard.title: A set of Common Software Quality Assurance Baseline Criteria for Research Projects

QC.Doc06.3.description: Does the project establish a code of conduct for its participants?
QC.Doc06.3.hint: A CODE_OF_CONDUCT file sets the path for a constructive, respectful and positive atmosphere among all the contributors in your software project. Of course you can define your own, but in case you want to rely on external and widely-adopted code of conducts check out some of the most popular ones: Contributor Covenant or Citizen Code of Conduct

evidence.message: A CODE_OF_CONDUCT file is not present in the code repository

standard.title: A set of Common Software Quality Assurance Baseline Criteria for Research Projects

QC.Doc06.2.description: Is there a clear path or guidelines on how to contribute to the code?
QC.Doc06.2.hint: A CONTRIBUTING file shall be present in the root path of the code repository describing the expected workflow to follow when adding contributions. Please check Mozilla's guidelines and GitHub's CONTRIBUTING.md example to get inspired on how to write a good CONTRIBUTING file

evidence.message: A CONTRIBUTING file is not present in the code repository

standard.title: A set of Common Software Quality Assurance Baseline Criteria for Research Projects

QC.Doc01.1.description: Are docs managed in the same repository as code?
QC.Doc01.1.hint: This subcriterion will succeed if the documentation files exist on the same repository as the source code, e.g. under a docs/ folder

evidence.message: Documentation resides in the same repository as code

standard.title: A set of Common Software Quality Assurance Baseline Criteria for Research Projects

QC.Doc02.X.description: Are docs following a style for the Markdown markup language?
QC.Doc02.X.hint: When using a docs-as-code approach, the style of the markup language is being checked. SQAaaS relies on markdownlint for Markdown files and restructuredtext-lint for reStructuredText

evidence.message: Docs are not fully compliant with markdownlint standard

standard.title: A set of Common Software Quality Assurance Baseline Criteria for Research Projects

QC.Sec02.description: Is the source code passing Static Analysis Security Testing (SAST)?
QC.Sec02.hint: Please check & solve the security weaknesses found by the SAST tool

evidence.message: Found security weaknesses when performing SAST checks with bandit tool

QC.Met01.hint: The two formats for software citation supported by SQAaaS are: 1) CodeMeta and 2) Citation File Format (CFF). While CodeMeta provides you with a more comprehensive description, CFF is a more lightweight, good-enough approach to software (with built-in support by GitHub) citation. Both provide tools (CodeMeta generator, CFFINIT)to easily generate a working citation file. Once having the file, be sure to add it to the root path of your code repo.

evidence.message:
No matching files found for language <CodeMeta> in repository searching by extensions or filenames
No matching files found for language <Citation File Format> in repository searching by extensions or filenames
